item.title: App Slop
item.description: I don‚Äôt want to be too verbose on this topic, but I think the era of app slop is upon us and the reasoning goes something like this: Vibe coding has real struggles - it works great in some cases, and the barrier to entry is very low However, unique anything is a recipe for hardship Business logic with more than one condition or multiple steps? Good luck! Tired Miyazaki is the ether of the vibe coding universe Thus those that persevere will have a downward pressure to simplify, simplify, simplify A proliferation of standard interactions will take place driven by the desire to survive the vibe shadcn/ui everywhere! Proportionally, creative UI/UX will diminish Everything becomes a suburban hellscape of bland utilitarian functionality Slop continues to take over Written slop is where it began Visual slop came next Now we are at the cusp of app slop This is probably a bit too pessimistic, and I don‚Äôt want to be that guy. I really am an optimist as far as general AI and technological things go. The above is partially a reflection of the darker moments of my vibe coding efforts coupled to having a little fun on guessing what realities may come to be. I have made great strides with vibe coding only to suddenly hit brick walls on some of the most basic novelties. It‚Äôs shocking, challenging, fun and frustrating. But I feel confident that there will be an ongoing pressure to create a miasma of sameness because it works, and people like to make stuff that works!

item.title: A short statistical reasoning test - Emir's blog
item.description: Each fraction has to be modelled as a distribution in order take its uncertainty into account. The binomial distribution is a good choice, such that k‚àºBinom(n,p) where k is the number of successes, n the number of trials and p the fraction of successful trials. We are given k and n, but we are interested in the distribution of p. There are many specific ways to produce a confidence interval for p, the lower bound of which can be used to order the fractions, and so control the risk of over-estimation.

item.title: Well, it seems you just don't like programming
item.description: I already tried to write a blog post about AI. An article, discussing AI generated art, still festers in my drafts folder. As someone who enjoys 3D modelling, drawing, animating, someone who believes in art lifting our spirits, I find it pointless and distasteful. Not much to discuss. Here are some loose thoughts about AI, mostly from software development perspective, but not unique to it. I see coding as both a skill, which enables me to build things I want to build, and an intellectual exercise. Like any other discipline, it doesn‚Äôt have sharp borders. If you‚Äôre receptive, if you pay attention, you‚Äôll learn things that apply outside of computer science. Underlying principles behind coding tell a bigger story, about systems, math, logic, or effective communication of ideas. Diving deeper into these ideas can become a source of great, personal satisfaction.
